g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Yet, financial consequences seem less important for deci
efficiency and renewable energy production than people indicate
Second, people are less likely to engage in mitigation behavio
rs that are unpleasurable or inconven
, and more likely to do so when they expect to derive positive feelings from such actions
etier et al. 1998; Steg 2005; Carrus et al. 2008; Brosch et al. 2014; Taufik et al.
. Positive feelings may be elicited when behavio
r is pleasurable, but also when it is perceived as
derdijk et al. 2013; Taufik et al. 2015)
Third, social costs and benefits can affect climate action
. People engage more in mitigation actions
when they think others expect them to do so and when others act as well
. Being part of a group that advo
(Biddau et al. 2016; Fielding and Hornsey 2016; Jans et al. 2018)
uncertainties and confirm benefits about adoption of renewable energy technology
. People may engage in mitigation actions when
they think this would signal something positive about them
2006; Kastner and Stern 2015; Noppers et al. 2014)
Social influence can also originate from political
GHG emissions are lower when legislators have strong
Fourth, mitigation actions, including saving energy and hot water, limiting meat consumption, and
investing in energy efficiency, resource efficiency in buildings, and renewable energy generation are
more likely when people more strongly care about others
2015; Steg et al. 2015; Wolske et al. 2017)
People across the world generally strongly value the
, suggesting that they are motivated to mitigate climate
The more individuals are aware of the
their actions can help reduce such impacts, which strengthens their moral norms to act accordingly, and
Groot 2010; Jakovcevic and Steg 2013; Chen 2015; Wolske
Initial mitigation actions can encourage engagement in other mitigation actions when people experience
that such actions are easy and effective
, and when initial actions make them realize
environmental person, motivating them to engage in more mitigation actions so as to be
(van der Werff et al. 2014; Lacasse 2015, 2016; Peters et al. 2018)
ate conditions that make it likely that initial mitigation actions motivate further actions.
effective energy sector mitigation strategies requires comparison
between the different mitigation options. One such metric is the cost of delivering one unit of energy,
for example, the levelized cost, or USD MWh
are useful because they normalize the costs per unit of service provided. While useful in characterizing
options in broad strokes, it is important to acknowledge and understand several caveats associated with
larly when applied globally. They may be constructed with different discount
rates; they require information on energy input costs for options that require energy inputs (e.g., fossil
electricity generation, biofuels); they depend on local resource availab
for solar power, wind classes for wind power, and rainfall and streamflow for hydropower; and actual
implementation costs may include additional elements, for example, the costs of managing electricity
ndent on VRE electricity sources. These complicating factors vary across regions,
some depend strongly on the policy environment in which mitigation options are deployed, and some
depend on how technologies are constructed and operated.
